markdownRemark.html:
Score: 100

factcheck.org  (WEB - en-US)

A nonpartisan fact-checking organization that primarily vets the statements of politicians.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

FactCheck.org is a project of the Annenberg Public Policy Center at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. The site is supported by donations made through the University of Pennsylvania, which is a separate nonprofit.

According to reports published on its funding page, in the 2018 fiscal year, Factcheck.org received $677,799 from the Annenberg Foundation, founded by Walter Annenberg, a philanthropist, media mogul, and former U.S. ambassador to the United Kingdom. In 2018, Factcheck.org also received $188,881 from Facebook, which in 2016 hired Factcheck.org and other fact-checking organizations to check potentially false news stories shared on its platform.

Other donors include the Stanton Foundation, founded by former CBS president Frank Stanton, which provided $150,000. Roughly 1,500 individual donors contributed a total of  $128,642 in 2018, the largest of which was a $10,000 donation from Pennsylvania attorney Richard Heller.

FactCheck.org states on its Our Funding page that it does not accept donations from “unions, partisan organizations or advocacy groups.” The organization says that it also does not accept contributions from corporations, with the exception of Facebook, which, the site states, “has no control over our editorial content.”  

The site has a Donate link on its homepage.

Content

FactCheck.org describes itself as “a nonpartisan, nonprofit ‘consumer advocate’ for voters that aims to reduce the level of deception and confusion in U.S. politics.” The site says it publishes fact checks of “TV ads, debates, speeches, interviews and news releases” from “major U.S. political players.” Unlike some other fact-checking organizations, such as PolitiFact.com and Snopes.com, Factcheck.org does not publish checks of claims the site’s researchers find to be true. “Our mission is to reduce the level of deception and confusion in U.S. politics, so we focus on claims that are false or misleading,” FactCheck.org states.

At the bottom of articles, the site publishes a “Share The Facts” box, a summary of the fact check, naming the person who made the claim, the statement made, and the verdict of the fact check. Verdicts include “False,” “Misleading,” and “Exaggerates.”

The site has sections devoted to different types of fact checks. One section includes content from the site’s initiative with Facebook to debunk false stories on the social media platform. Another reports on the organization’s partnership with CNN’s “State of the Union” program, which contains fact-checking videos. Sections are also devoted to fact-checking transcripts of U.S. President Donald Trump’s speeches and press conferences.

A science section examines what the site describes as “false and misleading scientific claims that are made by partisans to influence public policy.” The science section, which started with support from the Stanton Foundation, ranges from fact checks about climate-change claims to those on the opioid epidemic and the science related to mass shootings. The site also publishes a feature called Party Lines, which examines the truthfulness of political talking points by both major U.S. political parties.

The site’s fact checks are archived by topics, including President Trump, Paul Ryan, Chuck Schumer, Nancy Pelosi, Jobs, Climate Change, and Immigration, and are also grouped by month. The site averaged approximately 44 fact checks a month between January and November 2018, and roughly 35 fact checks a month in 2017, the organization said.

Credibility

Factcheck.org is a member of the International Fact-Checking Network, a unit of the Poynter Institute that certifies fact-checking organizations. The site has won a number of awards since its founding, including a 2018 Webby Award given to the best politics site on the internet and a 2010 Society of Professional Journalists excellence in journalism award for non-deadline reporting.

The site’s Our Process page states that the organization tries to devote “an equal amount of time reviewing claims by Republicans and Democrats. We do that by reviewing statements they make in the same venues.” Those venues include cable TV and Sunday talk shows, presidential remarks, TV ads, and press releases.

Articles generally link to sources and quote the experts who were interviewed for the story. The site lists examples of credible primary sources, including “the Library of Congress for congressional testimony; the House Clerk and Senate Secretary’s office for roll call votes; the Bureau of Labor Statistics for employment data; the Securities and Exchange Commission for corporate records; the IRS for tax data; the Bureau of Economic Analysis for economic data; and the Energy Information Administration for energy data.”

Eugene Kiely, the director of Factcheck.org, told NewsGuard that reporters seek comment from the people or organizations that made the statement under review. “Usually that’s the first thing we do,” he said. “Because it’s important to understand where they’re getting their information from.” The site often includes their comments in its reviews.

Headlines are straightforward and generally reflect the fact check’s conclusion. For example, a December 2018 article, headlined “Ocasio-Cortez’s Misguided Tweet,” states that “Rep.-elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tweeted that $21 trillion worth of ‘Pentagon accounting errors’ could finance two-thirds of Medicare for All. It can’t.” Some fact checks reach a mixed conclusion, such as one titled “Is Trump Responsible for Falling Gasoline Prices?” The verdict on that claim was “Not the Whole Story.” 

The site includes a corrections policy, stating: “If any new information comes to light after we publish a story that materially changes that story, we will clarify, correct or update our story and provide a note to readers that explains the change, why it was made and the date it was made.” The site regularly publishes corrections.

Transparency

The site’s Our Staff page provides detailed biographical information for each staff member and past contributors. Articles generally name the writer, and users can click on the byline to view an archive of that writer’s work. The Contact Us page includes a mailing address, general editorial email address, and two phone numbers.

The top of every page features the phrase “A Project of The Annenberg Public Policy Center.” The Our Funding page explains Factcheck.org’s relationship to the Annenberg Public Policy Center and how it is financed. The page also discloses financial information dating to 2010, including the amount of money given to the organization by the Annenberg Public Policy Center, Facebook, and others. The site names donors who have given more than $1,000.

The site does not run advertisements.

History

Factcheck.org was launched in 2003 by Brooks Jackson, a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal and CNN, and Kathleen Hall Jamieson, professor of communication at the University of Pennsylvania and director of The Annenberg Public Policy Center. Jackson remains as director emeritus of the center.

In 2012, Factcheck.org publicly defended an article that evaluated the claim of a political ad that then-President Obama’s re-election campaign ran against Republican candidate Mitt Romney, claiming that he had “shipped jobs to China and Mexico.” Factcheck.org found “no evidence to support the claim that Romney -- while he was still running Bain Capital -- shipped American jobs overseas.”

Obama’s campaign sent a six-page rebuttal to FactCheck.org and to news organizations, mostly disputing one element of the article — the contention that Romney stopped actively managing Bain Capital in February 1999 to run the Salt Lake City Olympics. Factcheck.org published the letter on its site, along with its own rebuttal, calling the Obama campaign’s claims “all wet.”

Written by:
Kate Harloe

Edited by:
Amy Westfeldt Eric Effron
